text: at the University of Arizona we focus on
two things the first is to discover new
information to create new knowledge and
the second is to transfer that new
knowledge of that information over to
future generations we have 43,000
students and we do 650 million dollars
worth of research career
we started our migrations to the cloud
in 2013 we sort of looked at public
cloud providers through the lens of an
enterprise compute pay so would we be
able to move enterprise level workloads
to this compute environment that we had
just largely used as consumers in 2014
we did roughly 20 small pilot
implementations we put three different
cohorts through AWS training having them
have practical real-world experience
using AWS to deploy enterprise level
workloads we invested pretty heavily in
things like training adding consulting
in areas where we didn't have a high
level of expertise we wanted to change
culture we invested in our people as
people began to experience opportunities
to work within the AWS environment a lot
of the concerns that they had about
operating in a new environment went away
pretty quickly we're able to do things
faster today than what we were able to
do them in 2013 with an on-premise
infrastructure we're minutes away from
being able to spin up new infrastructure
to be able to build applications or to
add new services for either our students
or for our faculty today that speed
actually opens up all kinds of other
benefits it frees up people it makes
things more predictable if you get
anything wrong you're only a few minutes
away from being able to go back and
making a change and correcting course
and being able to do it again our IT
staff they're able to be more responsive
I am most proud of the number of people
and the breadth of adoption that we have
had the advice that I would give myself
back in 2013 when we started our
attorney is that you can trust that it
works you're gonna run into all kinds of
obstacles with compute and storage and
network and security and everything and
there are solutions to every single one
of them
the tools and technology to be able to
comprehensively move workloads to the
cloud are all there
[Music]
